segments.source_content: Motion creator explains the animation tradeoffs of using View Transitions and why it makes sense for React to directly integrate it into its reconciler through a new `<ViewTransition>` component. This interactive post shows an early look at the upcoming React feature, including some of its current implementation details, and explains how it overlaps a bit with Motion layout animations.

translations.fr: Le crÃ©ateur de Motion explique les compromis d'animation liÃ©s Ã  l'utilisation des View Transitions et pourquoi il est logique pour React de l'intÃ©grer directement dans son rÃ©conciliateur via un nouveau composant `<ViewTransition>`. Cet article interactif montre un aperÃ§u prÃ©coce de la future fonctionnalitÃ© de React, incluant certains dÃ©tails d'implÃ©mentation actuels, et explique comment elle chevauche lÃ©gÃ¨rement les animations de disposition de Motion.
translations.en: Le crÃ©ateur de Motion explique les compromis d'animation des View Transitions et pourquoi il est logique que React l'intÃ¨gre directement dans son rÃ©conciliateur via un nouveau composant `<ViewTransition>`. Cet article interactif montre un aperÃ§u de la future fonctionnalitÃ© React, incluant des dÃ©tails d'implÃ©mentation actuels, et explique comment elle chevauche lÃ©gÃ¨rement les animations de disposition de Motion.

- ğŸ’¸ [Product for Engineers - Product management is broken. Engineers can fix it](https://dub.link/twir-jan15)

- ğŸ‘€ [Adopting the compiler at Wakelet](https://github.com/reactwg/react-compiler/discussions/52): Positive feedback, improving LCP and INP metrics. It did not magically solve all the perf issues, but was close to a â€œfree lunchâ€ experience.
- ğŸ“– [Next.js docs \- Single-Page Applications with Next.js](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/upgrading/single-page-applications): This new page notably documents how the newly released [SWR 2.3](https://github.com/vercel/swr/releases/tag/v2.3.0) now allows passing promises in `<SWRConfig fallback>`, enabling you to seamlessly move data fetching from the client to the server.
- ğŸ“œ [Understanding React Server Components](https://tonyalicea.dev/blog/understanding-react-server-components/): A comprehensive and well-presented overview of RSCs.
- ğŸ“œ [Accessibility essentials every front-end developer should know](https://martijnhols.nl/blog/accessibility-essentials-every-front-end-developer-should-know): Accessibility tips with React examples.
- ğŸ“œ [Bloated React code? Try component hooks](https://www.tymzap.com/blog/bloated-react-code-try-component-hooks): Reduce cognitive load by extracting a component hook so that the component can solely focus on rendering.
- ğŸ“œ [Make FormData and input names type-safe in React](https://www.typeonce.dev/article/make-form-data-and-input-names-type-safe-in-react): Using hand-made TS, then using Effect.Schema and FP.
- ğŸ“œ [Maybe don't navigate(-1) in Remix/React Router](https://programmingarehard.com/2025/01/13/maybe-dont-navigate-1.html/): Or how to navigate backward but ensure you never leave the current app.

- ğŸ“œ [Become expert in React Query](https://tigerabrodi.blog/become-expert-in-react-query)
- ğŸ“¦ [Next.js React Server Component Testing](https://github.com/kettanaito/nextjs-rsc-testing): An example repository of testing Next.js RSCs using MSW and Playwright.
- ğŸ“¦ [Nextra 4.0](https://the-guild.dev/blog/nextra-4): The Next.js-based docs framework upgrades to App Router among many other things.
- ğŸ“¦ [Base UI 1.0.0-alpha.5](https://base-ui.com/react/overview/releases)
- ğŸ“¦ [Superglue 1.0 \- React \+ Rails](https://thoughtbot.com/blog/superglue-1-0-react-rails-a-new-era-of-thoughtfulness)

segments.source_content: Meticulous creates and maintains an exhaustive suite of e2e ui tests with **zero** developer effort.

segments.source_content: This quote from the CTO of Traba sums the productÂ up best: "Meticulous has fundamentally changed the way we approach frontend testing in our web applications, fully eliminating the need to write any frontend tests. The software gives us confidence that every change will be completely regression tested, allowing us to ship more quickly with significantly fewer bugs in our code. The platform is easy to use and reduces the barrier to entry for backend-focused devs to contribute to our frontend codebase."

Le logiciel nous donne confiance que chaque modification sera entiÃ¨rement testÃ©e en rÃ©gression, nous permettant de livrer plus rapidement avec beaucoup moins de bogues dans notre code. La plateforme est facile Ã  utiliser et rÃ©duit le seuil d'entrÃ©e pour les dÃ©veloppeurs orientÃ©s backend afin de contribuer Ã  notre base de code frontend. Â»

segments.source_content: Expo unveiled what we expected, the first-ever universal app-hosting platform that completes the vision of bringing the web DX to the cross-platform world. It enables us to seamlessly deploy Expoâ€™s server-related features, notably Expo for Web, API Routes, and Universal React Server Components. It takes into account mobile app subtleties, such as syncing the backend/app versions. You can use either the CLI or CI (EAS Workflows). Under the hood, itâ€™s using Cloudflare Workers. Thereâ€™s a free plan.

translations.fr: Expo a dÃ©voilÃ© ce que nous attendions, la premiÃ¨re plateforme universelle d'hÃ©bergement d'applications qui concrÃ©tise la vision d'apporter la DX web au monde multiplateforme. Elle nous permet de dÃ©ployer de maniÃ¨re transparente les fonctionnalitÃ©s liÃ©es au serveur d'Expo, notamment Expo pour le Web, les routes d'API et les composants serveur React universels. Elle prend en compte les subtilitÃ©s des applications mobiles, comme la synchronisation des versions backend/app. Vous pouvez utiliser soit la CLI, soit l'intÃ©gration continue (EAS Workflows). Sous le capot, elle utilise Cloudflare Workers. Il existe un plan gratuit.
translations.en: Expo a dÃ©voilÃ© ce que nous attendions : la premiÃ¨re plateforme universelle d'hÃ©bergement d'applications qui complÃ¨te la vision d'apporter la DX web au monde cross-plateforme. Elle nous permet de dÃ©ployer de maniÃ¨re transparente les fonctionnalitÃ©s serveur d'Expo, notamment Expo pour le Web, les API Routes et les React Server Components universels. Elle prend en compte les subtilitÃ©s des applications mobiles, comme la synchronisation des versions backend/app. Vous pouvez utiliser soit le CLI soit le CI (EAS Workflows). Sous le capot, elle utilise Cloudflare Workers. Un plan gratuit est disponible.

segments.source_content: Shopify successfully migrated all their 6 apps to React Native, and shared a nuanced feedback summarizes well the tradeoffs of using React Native in practice. On the positive side we have: cross-platform support, performance, hot reloading, knowledge portability... You still need native knowledge, and a few things could be improved, such as the debugging experience and the ability to easily upgrade.

translations.fr: Shopify a migrÃ© avec succÃ¨s ses 6 applications vers React Native, et a partagÃ© un retour nuancÃ© qui rÃ©sume bien les compromis de l'utilisation de React Native en pratique. Du cÃ´tÃ© positif, nous avons : le support multiplateforme, les performances, le rechargement Ã  chaud, la portabilitÃ© des connaissances... Vous avez toujours besoin de connaissances natives, et quelques points pourraient Ãªtre amÃ©liorÃ©s, comme l'expÃ©rience de dÃ©bogage et la capacitÃ© Ã  mettre Ã  jour facilement.
translations.en: Shopify a migrÃ© avec succÃ¨s ses 6 applications vers React Native, et a partagÃ© un retour nuancÃ© qui rÃ©sume bien les compromis de l'utilisation de React Native en pratique. Du cÃ´tÃ© positif : support cross-platform, performances, hot reloading, portabilitÃ© des connaissances... Des compÃ©tences natives restent nÃ©cessaires, et quelques points pourraient Ãªtre amÃ©liorÃ©s, comme l'expÃ©rience de dÃ©bogage et la facilitÃ© de mise Ã  jour.

segments.source_content:
- ğŸ“£ [WinterTC (TC55) \- Technical Committee on Web-interoperable Server Runtimes](https://www.w3.org/blog/2025/collaborating-across-w3c-and-ecma-for-web-interoperable-server-runtimes-through-wintertc/): Supersede WinterCG, responsible for defining a Minimum Common API spec for server runtimes, aligned with web APIs.
- ğŸ“œ [Build systems and bundlers](https://github.com/orgs/web-infra-dev/discussions/24): Rspack maintainerâ€™s research on how build tools and bundlers implement their incremental mode.
- ğŸ“œ [Everything You Need to Know About Node.js Type Stripping](https://satanacchio.hashnode.dev/everything-you-need-to-know-about-nodejs-type-stripping): Tradeoffs explained by the Node.js PR author, including why `.tsx` files are not supported.
- ğŸ“œ [CSS text-box-trim \- Take back space from above/below, achieve optical balance](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/css-text-box-trim)
- ğŸ“œ [Updates to the customizable select API](https://una.im/select-updates/)
- ğŸ“œ [ECMAScript feature: import attributes](https://2ality.com/2025/01/import-attributes.html)

- ğŸ“¦ [Bun 1.1.43 \- S3 support, HTML bundling, V8 snapshots and more](https://bun.sh/blog/bun-v1.1.43)
